overview_of_class: What was Shakespeare's sex? We will read intensively a small set of plays and other texts by and about William Shakespeare in order to think about sex, sexuality, gender, and desire in his time and ours. How can we "translate" the foreign-yet-familiar languages and intensities of human interaction and emotion we read in Shakespeare into our own understanding? What acts, affections, emotions, and identities counted as "sex" in Shakespeare's time? How can we begin to understand the "sex" of a writer one of whose central skills was continually to cross-voice himself as a variety of women (and sometimes women as young men)? Alongside our close reading, discussion, and writing about A Midsummer Night's Dream, Venus and Adonis, Othello the Moor of Venice, The Two Noble Kinsmen, and Twelfth Night, Or What You Will, we will sample biographies (Shakespeare in Love) and feminist and queer criticism that attempt to answer the question of Shakespeare's sex.
name: First-Year Seminar
subject: ENGLISH

overview_of_class:
"The arts of building from the bee receive," urged Alexander Pope (Essay on Man, Epis. iii.1.175). From ancient civilizations to our time, architectural technique is but one of the bountiful gifts that honeybees (Apis mellifera a k a Apis mellifica) bestow upon our human world, from honey ("the flower transmuted, its scent and beauty transformed into aroma and taste"; Stephanie Rosenbaum, Honey: from Flower to Table), wax, and the myriad fruits and vegetables that depend on bees' nectar-gathering, pollinating labor to aeronautic, navigational, and engineering know-how, models of political and social order, medicinal benefits, and aesthetic inspiration.

Our seminar will be a collaborative workshop, a sort of virtual beehive, and our subjects will be selections from the scientific, historical, and aesthetic work on honeybees, from Aesop, Aristotle, Pliny, and Virgil through Mandeville, Maeterlinck, Pastorius, Karl von Frisch, and Muddy Waters to Richard Avedon, Tammy Horn, Lalinn Paull, to the current dangers of Colony Collapse Disorder. We'll explore honeybee ecology in relation to human culture through collaborative research and reading, documentary and feature films, and possible visits with experts on the science, natural and cultural history, and practical knowledge of bees. Each student will take an active part both in designing our common goals and in shaping lines of research and analysis for his or her own course projects. These will include a research paper and a personal essay or creative work. Like the honeybees, we'll be one for all and all for one, and everyone will gain and share experience in developing promising research questions, exploring and selecting relevant bibliography, critical thinking, and analytic and imaginative writing.
name: First-Year Seminar
subject: ENGLISH

overview_of_class: Many great works of literature are coming-of-age stories. As we accompany protagonists along their journeys to maturity, we watch them learn, fall in love, develop ambitions, encounter disappointment, and emerge?older and hopefully wiser?on the other side. We will read a few major novels in this course, including Great Expectations (Charles Dickens), Midnight's Children (Salman Rushdie), and Orlando (Virginia Woolf). As we put these engrossing works of fiction in dialogue with each other, we will focus especially on the relationship between individuals' aspirations and the ever-changing societies they inhabit. How do people come to understand themselves and the world around them? What causes protagonists to be rewarded or thwarted in their aims? Is the individual defined primarily by his social duty to others, or by his own desires? What forms can education take, and what kinds of knowledge do different educations afford? We will supplement our literary texts with short contemporary readings on topics such as higher education, ethics, and consumerism.
name: First-Year Seminar
topic: Precious Illusions: Growing Up in Literature
subject: ENGLISH

overview_of_class:
Does memory have a history? How do writers evoke and represent memories, and to what extent - and does it matter if - those representations are true to reality? How has the "art of memory" changed over time, and what "futures of memory" might we imagine? This course will consider changing concepts of memory, especially the metaphors we use to conceive of and talk about memory. While attending to the interdisciplinary nature of the topic of memory, the course will focus on representations of memories, remembering, forgetting, and commemoration in literature and culture. We will explore topics including classical and medieval concepts of memory and imagination, the relationship between memory and writing, memory and identity, nostalgia, how our senses trigger memories, trauma theory, collective memory and memorialization, and how changing technologies are changing our metaphors for and concepts of personal and collective memory.

Readings will include short fiction, poetry, essays, and academic writing by a variety of writers, including Augustine, James Baldwin, Elizabeth Bishop, Charles Bukowski, Jorge Luis Borges, Italo Calvino, John Donne, Mavis Gallant, Primo Levi, W.S. Merwin, Toni Morrison, Tim O'Brien, Vladimir Nabokov, Walker Percy, Plato, Marcel Proust, Natasha Trethewey, Frances Yates, and W.B. Yeats. We will also read articles on memory and cognition, memory and technology, and different possibilities writers and filmmakers have imagined for the future of memory, including the novella, The Memory Thieves, and episodes from the television show, Black Mirror.
name: First-Year Seminar
subject: ENGLISH

overview_of_class: In this seminar, we will examine the aesthetic properties of hip hop music that make it literary, on the one hand, and the social currents of hip hop culture that have routed it throughout the world, on the other hand. In our investigation of hip hop as literature, we will analyze how hip hop artists engage and reimagine traditional genres of poetry (ode, epic, and elegy) as well as how they have helped engender new ones (such as slam poetry). This aspect of the class will familiarize students with some of the aspects of prosody through such forms as slant rhymes, internal rhymes, and terza rima, among others. In our discussions of the migratory dynamics of hip hop, we will explore these routings (from the "streets" to Wall Street, from the Bronx to the suburbs, from the U.S. to the rest of the world) in relation to the idea of cultural currency.
name: First-Year Seminar
topic: The Rhyming Apparatus: Hip Hop as Poetry and Cultu
subject: ENGLISH

overview_of_class: Is it time, as some argue, to put the legacy of slavery behind us? This first-year seminar will explore debates about the relation of the present to the past by studying a broad range of contemporary narratives of slavery. We will examine depictions of slavery, as well as its shadow, across a range of African American literary genres, including the novel, short fiction, poetry, essays, and the graphic novel. Beginning in the 1960s, the tradition of the "neo-slave narrative" emerged within African American literature. We will investigate why and how this literary form developed and how the diverse texts that make up this tradition reimagine the past and reorient the present. Our explorations will center on the utility of different narrative modes, from realism to experimentalism, in addressing issues of loss, reparation, historiography, and cultural appropriation. We will begin with key 19th-century narratives by Frederick Douglass and Harriet Jacobs before turning to latter-day representations of slavery, including Toni Morrison's novel Beloved, Kyle Baker's graphic novel Nat Turner, stories from John Keene's Counternarratives, and Natasha Trethewey's poetry collection Native Guard. We will put these literary texts in conversation with other cultural narratives and remains of slavery, including the unearthing of the African Burial Ground in Manhattan, the visual art of Kara Walker, and the stories our own DNA can now tell through genetic genealogy.
name: First-Year Seminar
topic: The Present Past: Fictions of Slavery
subject: ENGLISH
